div.head: THE Morocco question. A GAME OF BLUFF. GERMAN ANSWER TO FRENCH NOT

div.p: It is understood that tho German answer to the French note will be presented in a few days, but Prince Radolin, will discuss its pur- port with M. Rouvier before its arrival. The impression now prevails in France that there is no ground for apprehension, and that a pacific solution is possible. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE. ARRIVAL AT DIVONNE.
div.p: London, June, 24. The Khedive has left om his homeward voyage ; the Earl of Cromer, Sir James Reunell Rodd, Sir E. H. Vincent Corbett, and General Slade bade him farewell at the station. (/f.)

The Earl and Countess of Londesbourgh entertained Ins Highness the Khediv at dinner on the 16th just, at their residence, S, South Audley-street. letter in the evening a concert was giveu, and Lord and Lady Loudes bo rough wore honored by the presence of their Royal Highnesses tho Crown Prince and Crown Princess of Sweden and Norway, their Royal Highnesses Prince Eugt'ue and Prince William of Sweden and Norway, and her Royal Highness Prince * Frederica of Hanover. The London Symphony Orchestra took part in the programme.
ic Franco-German question is following a course. The "Echo de Paris" learns England has entirely approved of M. (Havas.)

Hellenn Schools.—At 1030a.m. yeater day the annual distribution of prizes to the fourth class of the gymnasium and commercial department of the schools of the Greek com- munity of Alexandria took place. The cere momy was attended by his Beatitude Mgr Photios, Greek Orthodox Patriarch, and his clerical stall. M. N. Scotides, Hellenic Conaul- General at Alexandria, M. Benachi, president of the Greek community of Alexandria, and many other well-known members of the Hellenic colony An eloquent speech was delivered by M.Georgem .head master of the school. The distribution lasted till noon. To-day the summer holidays of these schools commence.

div.head: THE STATE RAILWAYS. FORMATION OF NEW BOARD.
div.p: We understand that Major Johnstone, whilst in England, selected a gentleman, thoroughly expe rienced in railway matters, who will be appointed as his special secretary. It is also said that a new board will be created, consisting of Mus- tapha Pasha Fehmy, Sir Vinoent Corbett, Sir William GaitUu, M. Barois, and Scandar Pasha Fehmy. The duties of the new board will be to consider and approve of all schemes involving the expenditure of large sum* of money, and they will only be called together to consider such questions. Beyond this, Major Johnstone and his colleagues will have entire responsi- bility in the management of the railways, and we understand that the former’s position will more resemble that of general manager of au English railway than it has formerly done, as was suggested in the report of the Railway Commission which visited this country. We publish this information under all reserve as we have received no official communica- tion concerning the changes which ate to be effected, but we believe that our anticipations will be found to be in the main correct.

div.head: RUSSIAN SICK AND WOUNDED.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon the American steamer "Garonne" arrived at Sues from Shanghai with Russian sick and wounded, on their way home on "parole." The vessel entered the Canal towards evening bound to Odessa.

div.head: SERIOUS STABbING AFFRAY SHIPS STEWARD ATTACKED
div.p: A serious affray took place in Alexandria harbour on Saturday at abont 1 p.m., just as tho S.S. "Avon" (Captain Lancaster)'was about to weigh anchor. The passengers had all beep embarked, and as it was lunch-timethe steward, J. E. Garnham, went to the galley to see about the meal. He found that the cook,.named John Raghy, had not prepared anything, and on asking for explanations he was furiously attack- ed by the Utter with a large kitchen knife measuring about lj feet. The man, who must have been intoxicated, inflicted an ugly gosh on tho steward’s right check, and the pair closed together, a terrible struggle taking place, in which the steward received stain in the head and the right arm. When the pair were separated by persons on board who heard the scuffle, the steward was seen to have suffered considerably at the hands of the aggressor. He was losing blood freely. The captain bandaged up his wounds and finally sent him to the Deaconesses’ Hospital, while the infuriated cook was taken to the British Consulate and placed in the lockup. A preliminary enquiry into the circum- stances of tho case was held by Mr. Gould on Saturday afternoon, when the prisoner was remanded for trial. The S.S. "Avon" left the harbour at 7.30 p.m. on Saturday. We understand that the wounded steward is doing as well as can be expected.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: The plague bulletin for last week, which is presented to us by the Sanitary Department, it somewhat alarming. As many as 26 cases have been notified during the week, which 18 deaths have been recorded and only one cure effected, namely, that of a European at Mit- Ghamr. Of the 26 new cases, 9 have occurred at Alexandria, 10 at Damanbour, 4 at Garois (Menoufieb) 1 at Fort Said, 1 at Zifta, and 1 at Barchoum-el-Sogra, Toukh district. Since January t, 1905,103 cases have been notified, as compared with 647 during the corresponding period last year. Yesterday's bulletin records a fatal cut at Alexandria, the victim being a native boy found dead at his home in Bab Sidra Barraui. Tbi* boy was a brother to the one who died on the previous day. A fatal case is reported from Port Said, 3 cases from Damanhour, one case from Ashmoun, and a recovery from Zifta.

div.head: THEFTS OF TELEGRAPH WIRE
div.p: Several times of late most daring thefts of telegraph wire have been committed on the Canal Company’s lines close to the office. Friday night again saw a complete Freak in communication between here and all canal stations, and on investigation being made it ias found that whole lengths of wire had been stolen from the post within a stone s throw of the office.

div.head: THE HBDJAZ RAILWAY.
div.p: Field Marshal Kiazim Pasha, Military Director of Works on the Imperial Hedjaz Railway, is expected to arrive here very shortly on an inspecting trip. Seven windmills on the Reinsch system are to be constructed for the Hedjaz railway. These windmills are to be used for raising water.

div.head: GROUNDING OF THE "FOYLE.’’
div.p: The British steamer "Foyle," laden with rice from Rangoon for Alexandria, is still aground near Hanish Island in the Red Sea, and her position is practically unchanged. Owing to the bad position in which she grounded, the salvage of the steamer and cargo is doubtful In the forehold there is 14 feet of water.

div.head: TUB S.S. "HELENE RICKMERS."
div.p: The German steamer "HELENE RICKMERS" which was ashore at Ras Garib, is still at San waiting for the lighters, which were left behind full of cargo owing to the bad weather. A tug was despatched from Sun a few days ago in search of the lighters, bat has not yet returned. A survey was held, and the steamer was found to have sustained no damage whatever. It appears that while the "Helene Rickmers" was aground she threw overboard over 4,000 bag* of rice.

Sues, Sunday. A telegram from Constantinople states that arrivals from Alexandria are subjected to 48 hours' quarantine and disinfection, while the rats on board must be destroyed. A telegram from Rome announces that arrivals in Italy from Alexandria are submitted to the measures and dispositions prescribed by sanitary maritime ordinance No. 5 of 1902, against plague According to this ordinance, all passengers, on arriving in an Italian port, must be medic- ally examined, and all personal or domestic effects which are not quite clean must be disinfected.

The Contagion of Example Shortly after midnight last Saturday a thief boarded the Cairo-Luxor express on the way to Magbagha and got into a first-class carriage which was occupied by Said Effendi Saleb, of the Native Parquet, and bis family. div.head: EXTRAORDINARY NEGLIGENCE
div.p: In our issue on the 7th inst. we referred to the discovery of a corpse dressed in European clothe* in a quarry pit near the Salt and Soda Company's works at Mex. The corpse was declared both by the . caracal and by the hospital staff to be that of a Sudanese. M. Georges Kanaan, a Syrian pharmacist, whore brother had been missing for some time.

The Right Rev. Jamas Bellotd, formerly Viear Apostolic of Gibraltar, died at Neiareth House, Southend, on Tuesday morning, after a long illness. Born in London io 1847, be wa* for twenty six years a British military chaplain, serving in the Zulu War and in the Egyptism Expedition under Lord Wolreley. He was wounded at Tel-el-Kebir.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Seti" sailed from Malta on Saturday morning and is due here to-morrow evening with passengers, mail, and general cargo

C1GAR AND UMBRELLA RACE-Thir teen entries made a big field in this race. One or two parasols suffered and one of the competi- tors planted his saddle dangerously near his pony's tail. Mr. Bartlett was first off but dropped the parasol be wielded, and Mr. Richmond came in winner
LADIES’ BICYCLE RACE. (Last in wins).— Won by Miss B. Allen. Mrs. Kelham was a good second.

POTATO AND BUCKET COMPETI- TION.-There were 20 entries for this event, but most of the performers seemed rather at sea. Mr. Jenkinson and Mr. Donaldson were finally given an extra ran, which was won by the former, who made the best individual ran in the event, getting in two potatoes out of three.

EGG AND SPOON RACE ON PONIES— This event brought 18 entries, including one lady, into the field, and was won by Mr. Hemp. Very few competitors arrived with their eggs unbroken. At the dose of the meeting, which did not last too long, Mrs. M. de C. Findlay kindly distributed the prizes, and receiv- ed the cheers of all present. The sheeting was thoroughly well organised by the A. S’O. was thoroughly well organised by the A. S'G. stewards and was greatly enjoyed by all present. The band of the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment played selections of music during the afternoon.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1205.
div.p: TARDON ON GOLF. if anyone has the right to lay down the law j on goll, nays the "Evening Standanl," it ia the m m who has won tho open championship four times—a record only equalled by the two Morrises, "Old Tom" and "Young Tom.” And in this book Harry Vardon shows that he is as jjoi 1 at preaching as at practioo. As an instruc- tor be is detailed but lucid. Thoroughly as he goes into the question o( grip, stance, swiDg, . ■md the correct use of each club, his explana- tions never become involved,and are materially helped out by a numbor of excellent reproduc- tions of the author porformiDg the strokes cot only in the right but also, by way of awful illustration, in the wrong way. These latter poses, wo hasten to add, Vardon found it "most inconveuient andjdifficalt" to assume. But they wear a fairly familiar look, somehow. Vardon addresses himself to an audience alike of beginners and of proficients. He keeps the "fancy" strokos in a separate cate- gory, howevor. To the boginner he is at the same time encouraging and depressing.' It is never too late to start. Even at forty or forty-five wo can reach scratch or very near it, but—at least three months' persis- tent and laborious practice is a tine qua non. As a shining example ho points to Mr. Balfour as having, it is stated, "spent a miserable fortnight in bunkers only, learning how to get out of them from every possiblo position.” It is interesting Jo hear that in Vardon’s opinion the Premier isnowa very good and steady player, and might be still better but for Parliamentary cares. Which is the master stroke in golf 1 That is another very interesting point on which he records his opinion. He awards tho palm to none of the ordinary shots, however perfect 1'he greatest is tho stroke to which a big pull or slice is intentionally applied for the accom- plishment of a specific purpose, which could nut be achieved in any other way.

“I call it the master shot because, to ac- complish it with any certainty and perfection, it is oo difficult even to the experienced golfer, because it calls for tho most absolute command over the club and every nerve and sinew of the body, and the courageous heart of the true sportsman whom no difficulty may daunt, and because, when properly done, it ia a splendid thing to soo, and for a certainty results in material gain to tho mab who played it" The best course in the world, in Vardon's estimation, is Sandwich. He acknowledges that he is at varianoe here with many of the best authorities on the gamo, but Ire gives good reasons for his choice. Prestwick and Hoy lake be puts next, but his verdict on St Andrews, passed, of course, before the reoent championships, is one of distinctly modified praise. It is "a good oourso generally, but its bunkers are badly placed." And here the author is certainly uot alone in his opinion. lu the lighter portion of his book, which, we must add, is written in really admirable style, Vardon has collected a number of delightful golf auecdot.-, with comparatively few chest- nuts among them. His visit to America in 1900, when he won the American Champion- ship, was notable, among other thing*, for the achievements of the reporters, who, trne to their tradition of sensationalism, annonnoed, one that he "carried away the green with his drive,” another that he "dropped dead at the hole.” Pacts, however, were as queer as fiction iu some parts of tho trip. On one Florida course men with sticks had to bo kept con- stantly employed on the greens to keep the locusts ofl the lines of the pntts !

But the best stories are to be found in the chapter "Conoeming Caddies.” There was a busy day on/jne occasion at North Berwick, when all the regular caddies were out, and fishermen were drafted into the service. A well known player engaged one of them, though the recruit acknowledged that he only knew very little of the game.

“This player happened to be left-handed, and took np his etanoe on the first tee aooord- ingly, whereupon the son of the sea at once’ adopted tho part of tutor, and with some warmth and show of ooutempt exclaimed loudly, ‘I dinna ken much about the game, l-t ye dinna keen a wee bit Mon, ye're stand- ing on the wrong side of the baw! Awa’ to . the other side ?' ”

More disconcerting and less amusing (to the player) was the following experience "Two golfers of some Highland eelebritywere playing a match one day at Luff ness, and after a hard round they came to the eighteenth tee all square and but this one bole to play. At this critical stage of the game the caddie of one of them approached bis master and nervously whispered to him, 'Please sir, wad ye do your very best here, for there’s money on this match.' And the goiter did try to do his very best indeed, but he pressed and he foozled, and he lost the hole and the match. Sympathetically he turned to his caddie to ask him what wus the amount of the lost wager that he might pay it for him and soften his disappointment ‘It was a penny, sir,' said Use boy.”

Mr. Balfour figures in more than one plea- sant little incident "He has a remarkable memory for the caddies who have served him, and onoe, when on the tee, just about to engage in a foursome, he re- cognised one of his opponents' caddies as a boy who on a former occasion had carried his own clubs, and be nodded to him kindly. Natarally the caddie was immensely pleased, and torn ing to one of bis colleagues fie remarked, ‘Ye see boo we Conservatives ken aue anither ” But we are inclined to think that the finest illustration of the "humanity" of the club- carfying class is to be fonnd in a story of a famous caddie nazped Sandy Smith. He "am- or,e day carrying for a player who had the good fortune to be no fewer than six holes np on his opponent by the time the eighth hole was reached. At this green something having gone wrong with tho reckoning of the strokes, there was a mild dispute as to whether the hole had been won by Sandy's man or whether it had boon halved. Bventually it was agreed that it was halved, bat as the players moved away to the next tee, he who was six down being ont of earshot in front, his opponent remarked to Sandy, ‘You know, Sandy, I still think I won that holo after all.' Sandy seemed shocked at such a cold-blooded greed for holes, nnd re- provingly, vory seriously, and sharply said to his employer, ‘Haud yor tongno, sir; haud yer tongue. Wad ye break the man's heart Vardon has much that is interesting to tell, too, in the way of reminiscence and of his observations in great matches. And whatever he has to say he says well. It is a book worthy of a place in the library of every golfer.

In “Country Life in Amerioa,” Mr. H.K. Job, an Amerioan naturalist, gives an account, illustrated by photographs, of an egret rookery he discovered in a southern State, unknown to the hnnter and rigorously protected. Ho says :—

A long sail up a series of narrow, tortuous creeks, between walls of impassable mud and through immonse salt marshes, found ns anchored at the desired locality. Even before the anchor took the mud, late in the afternoon, I had seen the sun glance on the dazzling whiteness of several dozens of egrets at they flew to and from the marsh, immaculate amid the southern mud whieh sticks like glue. After one false start, we found a man who knew the location of the rookery, in e greet oypress swamp. First we tramped a mile over a wood- land trail, whan we came to an arm of muddy wator under high, over-arching trees, and a small flat-bottomed skiff. Working two pad- dles wo glided along, and soon emerged in a great area of cypress trees growing out of the water. Alligators and turtles splashed be- fore us, end buzzards end ospreys wheeled overhead. From the cypress branches, with their delioate needle-foliage of pale green, hung the streaming grey moss. Pairs of wood-duck started up now sad then from INDIAN BANKS.

Possibly, as Governments. I*st week a small deputation, Although the movement for establishing peasants' banka in India seems tOj.mako very slow progress, it has undoubtedly gained ground in some localities. The ryot is, as m rule, conservative in all his tendencies, -and it has been found very difficult to oonvinoe these humble tillers of the soil that the time has come to break off financial relations with the village usurer. But even their obstinate addic- tion to ancient ways cannot g6t rid of the gain ooosequent on obtaining advances from banks at 12 per cent, instead of paying ten times that rate to some grasping money- lender on the same security. On first estab- lishment, the new institutions are invariably regarded with suspicion and dislike, all manner of libellous stories being disseminated by the pests they seek to supplant In one instance, the ryots were induoed to believe gthat the very latest devioe of the Siroar to disoover the innovation was the hidden taxable resources of the agricultural popu- lation. But the temptation to obtain loans on such comparatively easy oonditions led some of the more enlightened peasants to make trial of the new system, and when no harm resulted to these bold experimentalists, the more timorous embarked in the venture. It is calculated that by fixing the rate of interest as high as 13 per oent adequate provision is made for famine years and their inevitable losses. But that theory still requires to be put to the test; even the usurers suffer heavy losses at such times.
